story: Huge loudspeakers&nbspwhich blast out K-pop and criticism of Pyongyang fall silent for first time in more than two yearsSouth Korea has stopped broadcasting propaganda across its border with North Korea, in a gesture of goodwill ahead of historic talks between the two countries’ leaders this week.Dozens of huge loudspeakers, which blast out K-pop music, discussions of democracy, and criticism of Pyongyang’s regime, fell silent at midnight on Sunday for the first time in more than two years.The move comes with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and South Korean president Moon Jae-in due to meet at ‘truce village’ Panmunjom in the demilitarised zone straddling the two countries. North Korea announces it will stop nuclear tests and missile launchesIt is not yet clear if Pyongyang, which itself broadcasts praise for its leader and patriotic songs across the border, will reciprocate by silencing its speakers.“We hope this decision will lead both Koreas to stop mutual criticism and propaganda against each other and also contribute in creating peace and a new beginning,” Seoul’s defence ministry said.The move followed North Korea’s surprise announcement that it would halt nuclear tests and missile launch trials. Pyongyang also said it was closing down a nuclear test site and would instead pursue economic growth and peace.The decision has been welcomed by world leaders, including US president Donald Trump, who is set to meeting Mr Kim next month.Mr Moon said: “North Korea’s decision to freeze its nuclear programme is a significant decision for the complete denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula. It is a green light that raises the chances of positive outcomes at the North’s summits with South Korea and the United States.He added that if North Korea goes the path of complete denuclearisation, “a bright future” for the secretive communist state can be guaranteed. North Korea – South Korea relations: in picturesNorth Korea – South Korea relations: in picturesA solid-fuel Pukguksong-2 missile lifts off during its launch test in North Korea on May 22, 2017. They said that it was examining operational plans for attacking Guam, an angry reaction to UN punishment for previous North Korean intercontinental ballistic missile tests and a US suggestion about preparations for possible preventive attacks to stop the North's nuclear weapons program.North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un inspecting a launching drill of the medium-and-long range strategic ballistic rocket Hwasong-12 at an undisclosed location.&#13President Donald Trump talks with South Korean President Moon Jae-In during their joint press conference at the presidential Blue House on November 7, 2017 in Seoul.Trump was the first US President to address the South Korean National Assembly since President Clinton in 1993. He addressed Kim Jong Un warning him to not underestimate the US and that for talks to materialize then Pyongyang would need to take steps into denuclearization. Haean-Myeon, is a small military town near the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) and border between North and South Korea, in Gangwon province. The zone is a strip of land running across the Korean Peninsula and was created after the 'Korean Armistice Agreement'. Any negotiations between the two countries tend to take place in this zone.President Donald Trump speaks to the media during a cabinet meeting at the White House on November 20, 2017, where he officially designated North Korea as a state sponsor of terrorism. North Korea had previously been on the list, however was removed in 2008.The North Korean government launches it's Hwasong-15 intercontinental ballistic missile at an undisclosed location in North Korea on November 29, 2017. It is supposedly capable of reaching all parts of the US. North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un celebrating the launch of the Hwasong-15 missile on November 29, 2017.North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un delivering his New Year's speech. He vowed North Korea would mass-produce nuclear warheads and missiles in a defiant New Year message on January 1 suggesting he would continue to accelerate a rogue weapons programme that has stoked international tensions. Fireworks are seen above the Taedong River during New Year celebrations as visitors pose for a photo in front of an ice sculpture of an intercontinental ballistic missile at the Pyongyang Ice Sculpture Festival in Kim Il Sung Square in North Korea on 1 January, 2018.South Korean President Moon Jae-in talks with US President Donald Trump on January 4, 2018 in Seoul. South Korea and US agreed to delay  the annual Foal Eagle military drills until after the PyeongChang Winter Olympic Games in an effort to de-conflict the Games and focus on ensuring the security of the event.Vehicles transporting the South Korean delegation, led by South Korean Unification Ministrer Cho Myoung-Gyon, drive past a checkpoint on the road connecting South and North Korea at the Unification Bridge, near the Demilitarized zone (DMZ) separating them both on January 9, 2018 in Paju. They began their first official face-to-face talks in two years.Members of the South Korea delegation (R) shake hands with members of the North Korean delegation (L) during their meeting at the border truce village of Panmunjom in the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) iding the two Koreas on January 9, 2018. They focused on the forthcoming Winter Olympics after months of tensions over Pyongyang's nuclear weapons programme.Foreign Ministers from twenty countries from North and South America, Asia, and Europe pose for a photo at the Vancouver Foreign Ministers Meeting on Security and Stability on the Korean Peninsula, in Vancouver on January 16, 2018. The US urged an escalation in pressure on North Korea over its nuclear missile program, despite a more cautious tone from key US ally South Korea. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, co-hosted the event with Canada's foreign minister Chrystia Freeland, and called for North Korean ships to be intercepted and for new punitive measures to be implemented every time Pyongyang tests new weapons.PyeongChang 2018 Olympics President Lee Hee-beom, North Korea's Sports Minister and Olympic Committee president Kim Il Guk, International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach, South Korean Minister of Culture, Sports and Tourism Do Jong-hwan and South Korea's National Olympic Committee President Lee Kee-heung join their hands as they pose during a signing ceremony at the Olympic Museum on January 20, 2018 in Lausanne.&#13Anti-North Korea activists burn a portrait of leader Kim Jong-Un during a rally Seoul Station as a North Korean delegation arrived to check out performance venues for the Winter Olympics on January 22, 2018. Protesters led by the Korean Patriots Party gathered and complained that the talks to encourage North Korea's participation is stealing the spotlight from their country to the benefit of the regime.South Korean soldiers stand guard at the border village of Panmunjom in the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) between South and North Korea on February 7, 2018. In a sign of thawing bilateral ties, North Korea today announced that Kim Yo-jong, the sister of North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, will attend the opening ceremony of the PyeongChang Winter Olympic Games.  North Korean ferry Mangyongbong-92 carrying a 140-strong orchestra approaches a port in Donghae, South Korea, February 6, 2018.  A member of a conservative civic group tears a portrait of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un during an anti-North Korea protest as the North Korean ferry Mangyongbong-92 carrying a 140-strong orchestra approached.A North Korean flag is seen hanging on a building at the Winter Olympics athletes village in Gangneung, South Korea.Democratic People's Republic of Korea Vice Sports Minister Won Gil-woo receives a gift from mayor of the Olympic Village Kim Ki-hoon during the welcome ceremony ahead of the PyeongChang 2018 Games at the Olympic Village on 8 February, 2018 in South Korea.US Vice President Mike Pence shakes hands with South Korean President Moon Jae-in before their meeting at the presidential office in Seoul, South Korea on 8 February, 2018.South Korea’s defence ministry did not say if the propaganda broadcasts would resume following this week’s summit.The transmissions, designed to sow doubt about Pyongyang’s official message among North Korean troops and citizens near the border, have long been a source of tension between the two nations. Both countries have employed the tactic intermittently since the end of the Korean War in 1953.The speakers have been in regular usage since the North’s nuclear test in January 2016, which began a prolonged period of escalating global tensions over Pyongyang’s weapons programme.This week’s talks and the planned meeting between Mr Kim and Mr Trump have raised hopes of an easing in those tensions, which reached a crescendo last year amid a flurry of North Korean missile launches and its largest nuclear test.The American leader hailed Pyongyang’s announcement that it was freezing its nuclear programme as “very good news for North Korea and the World”.He added: “Big progress! Look forward to our Summit.”Kim Jong-un’s offer to end nuclear tests is a major test for TrumpHowever, he sounded a more cautious note, writing on Twitter: “We are a long way from conclusion on North Korea, maybe things will work out, and maybe they won’t – only time will tell.”The US president had earlier claimed in a tweet that North Korea “agreed to denuclearisation”.In fact, Pyongyang stopped short of suggesting it would give up its existing nuclear weapons or scale back production of missiles and their related component parts. “As the weaponisation of nuclear weapons has been verified, it is not necessary for us to conduct any more nuclear tests or test launches of mid- and long-range missiles or ICBMs,” Mr Kim said, according to North Korean news agency KCNA. “The northern nuclear test site has completed its mission.”He added: “The whole party and the whole nation should now focus on the development of the socialist economy. story: Kate and Prince William couldn&rsquot stop smiling as they waved to the crowd with their royal newborn son on the steps of the Lindo Wing at St Mary's Hospital.It's tradition to debut the royal baby on the hospital steps in front of a battalion of paparazzi and crowds.And it's where the very first photos of Prince George and Princess Charlotte were taken just outside the Lindo Wing at St. Mary's Hospital in London.Prince George, the Duke and Duchess' first baby, was born on July 22, 2013 and Kate and Prince William introduced their son to the world in matching light-blue outfits.When Princess Charlotte was born early in the morning on May 2, 2015, the couple debuted their daughter on the Lindo Wing steps later that evening. The Duchess wore a bright floral dress, and Prince William donned a vibrant blue sweater, which was fitting for the baby's spring birthday.Princess Diana first revealed Prince Harry and Prince William on the same stairs after their births.Hear are the first photos of Prince George, Princess Charlotte and of course, the new royal baby on those famous hospital steps.

title: Brexit News BETRAYAL Stephen Kinnock Brexiteers customs union
story: A symbolic vote this Thursday in the House of Commons on the fate of the customs union after Brexit could inflict an embarrassing defeat to Theresa May.However, Stephen Kinnock, a prominent Labour MP, has said that this is not the real reason why Brexiteers like Liam Fox, David Davis and Boris Johnson, are so angry.The prominent pro-Brexit figures in the cabinet have threatened to take Theresa May to task over a potential backtrack.Downing Street today insisted the Government was committed to leaving the EU's customs union.&nbsp TALKRADIOThe prominent pro-Brexit figures in the cabinet have threatened to take Theresa May to task                Brexit News: Custom union 'plot' will help EU achieve its 'agenda'Mr Kinnock, a Remainer, dismissed the idea that this Thursday's vote could force the Government's hand on the future.Instead, he told Julia Hartley-Brewer that the real reason Brexiteers are furious is concerns over Mrs May's apparent preference for a customs partnership.The Remain MP told talkRadio: The vote on Thursday is not a binding vote. It&rsquos just a one-line whip. A vote pushed by backbenchers, not the front bench.The vote on Thursday won't be a make-or-break moment.Hartley-Brewer asked why Brexiteers like David Davis and Boris Johnson were so angry and facing up to the Prime Minister ahead of the vote.Kinnock, a Remainer, dismissed the idea that this Thursday's vote could force the Government's handMr Kinnock responded: I think they are worried about the briefing coming from No 10.There was a line over the weekend, that Mrs May won&rsquot be crying into her beer if she is forced into a customs union.&nbspBrexiteers can sense now that their more sensible and pragmatic Conservative colleagues are actually not going to back down.Lord Digby Jones, a Brexiteer, blasted the planned vote on Thursday as politicising somthing that transcends politics.He said: This smacks of a party trying to embarrass Government. For God's sake we have to understand we're leaving.Last Wednesday, the government suffered defeat on the EU Withdrawal Bill in the House of Lords - when peers voted in favour of staying in the customs union.On Thursday rebel Tories plan to defy the Government by urging ministers in a symbolic, non-binding, vote to make establishing &ldquoan affective customs union an aim in Brexit talks.If the UK remains part of the customs union, it would be unable to strike trade deals with countries around the world.

title: brexit news house of lords theresa may eu laws
story: EPATheresa May suffers a setback on her Brexit plansHouse of Lords peers voted by 316 to 245 in favour of enshrining the EU's Charter of Fundamental Rights into UK law in defiance of opposition from ministers.The Government is now expected to try to overturn the reversal in a Commons vote next month.Ministers had warned that a proposed amendment to the Government's EU Withdrawal Bill would enshrine a body of foreign law onto Britain's statute book.Tory frontbench peer Lord Keen said: The idea we'd have to cling onto a body of foreign law in order to maintain fundamental human rights in this country is simply astonishing.                Brexiteer rips into Remainer calls to keep UK in EUHe added: It would reflect not only a constitutional outrage but a total abdication of our responsibilities.Crossbench peer Lord Pannick tabled the amendment to the Withdrawal Bill to transfer the EU Charter - a text incorporating European political, civic, economic and social rights - into British law.He claimed exclusing the measure would conflict with the Withdrawal Bill's aim of transferring Brussels legislation into British law to ensure a smooth exit from the bloc.Lord Pannick claimed excluding EU rights from domestic law would lead a recipe for confusion after Brexit.House of Lords voted in favour of enshrining the EU's Charter of Fundamental Rights into UK law A spokesman for the Department for Exiting the EU said: &ldquoWe are disappointed that the House of Lords has voted for this amendment in spite of the assurances we have provided.&ldquoThe Charter of Fundamental rights was never the source of rights in the UK &ndash it simply reaffirmed rights that already existed in EU law and the EU (Withdrawal) Bill will convert this EU law into UK law.We will review this decision when the Bill returns to the House of Commons to ensure we deliver a workable piece of legislation that provides certainty as we leave.The reverse follows two previous Lords defeats for the Government last week on the Brexit legislation.Later, the Government suffered another defeat in the Lords when peers backed an amendment designed to prevent ministers from specify in regulations when people can bring legal challenges against the validity of EU rules transferred into UK law. Peers voted by 285 to 235 in favour of the amendment.Ministers suffered a third defeat when peers backed an amendment seeking to maintain a right of legal action from any failure to comply with the general principles of EU law. Peers voted by 280 to 223 in favour of the move.

title: brexit news jurgen klopp liverpool leave eu second brexit vote
story: IMAGESBrexit news: J&uumlrgen Klopp has expressed his support for a second Brexit voteThe 50-year-old German said the split &ldquomakes no sense at all and said he thought those who voted in favour of Britain leaving the EU were now regretting their choice.Mr Klopp, who has led Liverpool to the semi-finals of this season&rsquos Champions League run as well as presiding over an impressive Premier League campaign, said the European Union was &ldquonot perfect but described it as &ldquothe best idea we had.He also heaped praise on Angela Merkel, who he said is &ldquodoing an unbelievable job.Giving his views on the EU referendum, he said: &ldquoWhen Mr Cameron had the idea you thought: &lsquoThis is not something people should decide in a moment.&rsquo                Liverpool news: Jurgen Klopp reveals his shock at Brexit decision                I DON&rsquoT see the point of Brexit, says Liverpool boss&ldquoWe are all influenced by the way only some of the argument is given, and once the decision is taken nobody gives you a real opportunity to change it again.&ldquoThe choice was either you stay in Europe, which is not perfect, or you go out into something nobody has any idea how it will work.&ldquoSo you give people the chance to make this big decision. And then it&rsquos a 51-49 vote and you&rsquore thinking: &lsquoWow, 49 percent are not happy with the decision that&rsquos going to change the country.&rsquo&ldquoFor the 51 percent, I&rsquom sure they realised pretty early after the vote: &lsquoWhat have we done?&rsquo IMAGESJ&uumlrgen Klopp said Brexit &lsquomakes no sense at all&rsquoMr Klopp went on to say the events following the vote in June 2016 were proof key Brexit campaigners did not expect to win.He told the : &ldquoThe two leaders of the Leave campaign then stepped aside. It was a pure sign they were surprised themselves by the vote.&ldquoOK, that can happen. But then, come on, let&rsquos sit together again. Let&rsquos think about it again and let&rsquos vote again with the right information &ndash not with the information you&rsquove got around the Brexit campaign.&ldquoThey were obviously not right, not all of them. It makes no sense at all. IMAGESThe Liverpool manager said those who voted for Brexit were now thinking &lsquowhat have we done?&rsquoMr Klopp, who was born in former West Germany, is contracted to manage Liverpool until 2022.He went on to acknowledge the EU had its faults but insisted Britain would be better off as a member.And he said people he has talked with who voted Remain have yet to speak out because they have yet to feel the impact of the Leave vote.Mr Klopp said: &ldquoWhen I speak to people they say, &lsquoI wanted to stay but I don&rsquot want to talk about it because I don&rsquot feel it yet as a person.&rsquo IMAGESJ&uumlrgen Klopp has led Liverpool to the semi-finals of the Champions League&ldquoI feel it constantly because since I came here the pound dropped. People go on holiday and say: &lsquoSpain is very expensive!&rsquo&ldquoBut it&rsquos only because the pound is not that strong anymore. The EU is not perfect but it was the best idea we had.&ldquoHistory has always shown that when we stay together we can sort out problems. When we split then we start fighting.&ldquoThere was not one time in history where ision creates success. So, for me, Brexit still makes no sense.His latest comments come just days after he attracted the ire of Brexit supporters following an interview with the , in which he questioned the benefits of the decision to split with Brussels.

title: mandy richards jeremy corbyn labour parliamentary candidate worcester
story: NCMs Richards is a teacher and youth justice case worker from HackneyFar-Left Momentum activist Mandy Richards has been selected as Labour&rsquos parliamentary candidate for the key marginal of Worcester, despite having 14 restraining orders from the courts and a history of being a conspiracy theorist.Ms Richards, a teacher and youth justice case worker from Hackney, has been photographed with Mr Corbyn and other leading Left wing figures including Owen Jones.Among the conspiracy theories she has expressed on Twitter is an implication that the Manchester Arena bomb was invented.She posted messages asking why there was no damage photographed including: &ldquoCan news agencies, police or anyone else for that matter explain why still no imagefootage of physical damage at Manchester arena?                Labour in CHAOS: Front-bench isions over immigration stance EXPOSED                Labour selects SERIAL &lsquoconspiracy&rsquo theorist as election candidateShe described the murder of Labour MP Jo Cox as an &ldquoincident conveniently bereft of evidence.She also said the death of Sister Sledge singer Joni Sledge was part of a plot saying: &ldquoHow many more shock celebrity deaths before high incidence called into question?And she posted a video suggesting footage from the Westminster terror attack was dishonestly edited.Ms Richards is currently subject to 14 civil restraining orders because of vexatious claims she has made against a series of people including MI5, the British Army, Thames Water, Hackney Council, her GP, the freeholder of her flat and even shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott who gave evidence against her in court.James Cleverly, deputy chairman of the Conservative PartyShe has accused organisations and iniduals of putting her under surveillance, tampering with her car, bicycle, mail, breaking into her home and failing to stop alleged attempts to poison her.Tonight former Labour MP Mike Foster, who represented Worcester from 1997 to 2010, said Ms Richards should be sacked.James Cleverly, deputy chairman of the Conservative Party said: &ldquoIt says something about the workings of the current Labour Party that a fantasist and conspiracy theorist can become, and remain, a selected parliamentary candidate.Tonight Ms Richards said she was a &ldquovictim of domestic harassment and that she was &ldquovindicated by the evidence uncovered and by the Judge&rsquos recommendations that the processes in question should be reviewed given that they could well have been open to abuse.

title: brexit news theresa may confront remainer eu mps customs union plot
story: Theresa May is being told to fight back against those plotting to disrupt BrexitThe Prime Minister has so far chosen to avoid confrontation with those MPs refusing to tow the party line but is now being told by her allies to confront those plotting against her Brexit plan.Leave campaigners are calling for the PM to hold a Commons vote in a showdown with those attempting to sabotage EU negotiations.Iain Duncan Smith said: &ldquoAt some point the Government will have to have a vote, and when they do I am sure they&rsquoll win it.&ldquoWe have a manifesto commitment to leave the Custom Union, and all my colleagues will be reminded of that.                Brexit news: EU boss replied to Rees-Mogg border in furious fashion                Former Brexit minster slams EU for refusing to talk about tradeThe Government has repeatedly pledged it will leave the Customs Union after Brexit in order to represent what it sees to have been the will of those who voted leave in the 2016 referendum.However, Mrs May is said to be afraid of being so bold as to call a vote in Parliament on the issue in fear she would lose, majorly damaging her authority.A close ally of the Prime Minister told the Sun: &ldquoShe is in a trap. She needs the space to get one of her proposals agreed with the EU.&ldquoBut clearly they won&rsquot do that as long as they think Parliament will vote for a Customs Union.David Davis meets EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels ahead of a crunch meeting of European Union leaders later this week                    AFPGetty Images1 of 10British Brexit minister David Davis (L) and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier meet at the European Commission in BrusselsThe issue of the Customs Union resurfaced after the House of Lords voted in favour of an amendment to the EU withdrawal Bill which seeks to maintain the possibility of Britain staying in the bureaucratic trade bloc.The Bill will now be debated in the House of Commons on Thursday.Mrs May is believed to currently be urging ministers to stay away from the Chamber during the debate in order to try and minimise its significance.Despite refusing to confront those looking to betray her, the Conservative leader has refused to waiver from her position the UK will leave the Customs Union.Boris Johnson has supported the Prime Minister's Customs Union stanceA No 10 spokesman said: &ldquoThe Prime Minister is very clear that we are leaving the Customs Union and that we will have the freedom to strike our own trade deals.Members of the Cabinet have also supported the Prime Minister for sticking to her official position on the matter.In a public display of support, Boris Johnson said: &ldquoWe have to change our relationships with the institutions of the EU and that clearly means coming out of the customs union, out of the single market.

title: UK weather April misery April showers wet soggy weather heatwave dissipates
story: A large area of rain will fall on Wales on Tuesday morning courtesy of a weather frontA large area of rain will fall on Wales on Tuesday morning courtesy of a weather front, before spreading across large parts of the UK.Meteorologist Alex Deakin said: &ldquoIt does look like quite a soggy morning across west Wales.&ldquoThere will be rain at times over the Midlands and eventually extending into eastern England.The wet weather across large parts of Wales may intensify throughout the afternoon, and could spread into parts of northern England.Heavy bursts of rain may also be seen in the Midlands, southern Scotland and Northern Ireland.                How to sleep: Surefire ways to sleep in a heatwave                UK weather WARNING: Britain to be battered by frost, hail and SNOWHeavy bursts of rain may also be seen in the Midlands, southern Scotland and Northern IrelandThe south of England will escape the heaviest rain, but conditions will remain volatile.Mr Deakin said: &ldquoParts of the south will just be a bit drizzly, but there will be murky conditions, and it will be really quite misty along the south coast with a brisk breeze.There is however hope for slightly better weather in northern England, with clear, sunny spells.Mr Deakin notes: &ldquoNorthern Britain will have a very different day with sunny spells, but there will be showers.Temperatures will remain relatively warm at 12 or 13 degrees Celsius, but it will feel a lot cooler compared to this time last week.The weather front entering the UK has a wave, which means rain forecasts for the coming day are relatively unpredictable.Mr Deakin said: &ldquoThere is still some uncertainty about how much rain we will see on Tuesday, and just how far north this pulse of rain will get.This uncertainty remains into Wednesday, but the weather front will generally clear throughout the day, bringing in cooler air.The UK is experiencing the hottest April day in age, with temperatures hit the high 20s across the country                    Dinendra HariaWENN1 of 8Today is officially the warmest April since 1949The departing weather front will remove the cloud and for many Britons it will be a sunny start to Wednesday.This will however be combined with intermittent showers throughout the day.Commenting on Wednesday&rsquos weather, Mr Deakin warns: &ldquoIt&rsquos a classic April day with sunny spells and then the next minute you&rsquove got a shower on your hands.Average temperatures will be about average for this time of year, hovering between 10 to 15 degrees Celsius.

story: WATCH: Moment antifascists clash with police at Franco-Italian border                Donald Trump hosts Macron for CRUNCH state visit - 'All or nothing'But the rolling strikes against a planned overhaul of the state-owned SNCF rail company, a strike by Air France staff over pay and student protests over the planned university reform have put a dent in Mr Macron&rsquos approval ratings, a poll showed on Sunday.The Ifop poll for the conservative weekly Le Journal du Dimanche (JDD) showed that 55 percent of French people now disapprove of his actions as president.Only 44 percent of respondents said they approved of Mr Macron&rsquos actions, down from 52 percent in December.Although the strikes and protests have cast a harsh light on the government&rsquos reform agenda, which critics have said is being implemented at a punishing pace, not all French people support the anti-government movements.In fact, most people in France think that the rolling strike action against the railway reform &ndash which has plunged the country into travel chaos &ndash is not justified, according to an Ifop poll published on Sunday.The poll, also conducted by Ifop for the JDD, showed that 57 per cent of French people do not support the striking rail workers and that 61 per cent want the government to push ahead with its reform plans.Only 43 per cent of respondents told pollsters the rolling rail strikes &ndash which kicked off on April 3 and are due to end on June 28 &ndash were justified.France&rsquos four main rail unions, including the CGT, have called the two-day rolling strikes to protest against plans to open the debt-ridden SNCF monopoly to competition as required by EU law.15,000 have taken to the streets in Paris today over proposals to reform the France's strict labour code                    REUTERS1 of 14Tear gas floats in the air near French CRS riot policeThey are also contesting plans to scrap rail workers&rsquo job-for-life guarantees, automatic annual pay rises and early retirement scheme.The Ifop approval ratings poll of 1,949 people was carried out between April 12 and April 21, while the poll of 1,009 people about the French strike movement was carried out between April 20 and April 21.
